Dance, music and theater decked out for the holiday

Elizabeth Kramer, ekramer@courier-journal.com 10:12 a.m. EST December 5, 2014

The Bolshoi Ballet’s production of “The Nutcracker” will be broadcast to movie theaters nationwide on Dec. 21.(Photo: Damir Yusupov)

Story Highlights

  • Actors Theatre of Louisville has a completely new look for "A Christmas Carol" with new sets props and and costumes.
  • Former arts leader Tim King is singing in Indiana University Southeast's Holiday Pops Spectacular.
  • Former Louisville Ballet dancer Dale Brannon in "Nutcracker" with students from area dance schools.
13 CONNECT 10 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

While some people revel in the traditional performances of "A Christmas Carol" or "The Nutcracker" each December, others enjoy the more offbeat offerings of the Louisville area arts community, such as "The Kings of Christmas" featuring an Elvis impersonator.

There's also a range of holiday music sung by an array of choral groups and special art exhibits and art sales that bring a welcome change to the usual shopping experiences this season can bring.

All the events are arranged by date.

DANCE

"Clara's Dream"

University of Louisville Dance Theatre with the University Symphony Orchestra

Comstock Concert Hall, U of L School of Music, Belknap Campus

Dec. 5, 7 p.m.; Dec. 6, 3 and 7 p.m.; Dec. 7, 2 p.m.

This adaptation of "The Nutcracker" includes Clara's dream as she journeys to the Land of Sweets, where she's entertained by dancing toy soldiers, cotton candy angels and the Sugar Plum Fairy. Information: (502) 852-6878; louisville.edu/music.

COURIER-JOURNAL

Holiday TV - from the Grinch to Charlie Brown

"The Nutcracker"

Sacred Heart School for the Arts

Ursuline Arts Center, 3105 Lexington Road

Dec. 12, 7 p.m.; Dec. 13, 2 and 7 p.m.; Dec. 14, 2 p.m.

This "Nutcracker" production includes 54 dancers from 13 studios throughout the Louisville area, along with 59 dancers from the Sacred Heart School for the Arts dance program. Dale Brannon, principal dancer with the Louisville Ballet from 1981 to 2001, will dance the role of Herr Drosselmeyer. Directed by Julie McWilliams and choreographed by McWilliams, Amanda Johnson and Daylena Ruiz Garcia. Information: (502) 897-1816; www.showtix4u.com.

The Brown-Forman "Nutcracker"

Louisville Ballet

Kentucky Center, Whitney Hall, 501 W. Main St.

Dec. 6-21

This "Nutcracker" version with Marie, her Nutcracker prince and the timeless music of Tchaikovsky played by the Louisville Orchestra and choreography by Val Caniparoli returns as a local holiday favorite and tradition. After facing the ghastly Rat King and his followers, the two set off on a trip to another world of fairies, flowers and dancers from an array of cultures. Information: (502) 584-7777; www.louisvilleballet.org, www.kentuckycenter.org.

"Nutcracker in a Nutshell"

MAGIC Dance Company

Louisville Palace Theater, 625 S. Fourth St.

Dec. 6, 2 and 7 p.m.

A shorter version of "The Nutcracker" with new choreography that features the battle between mice and soldiers and Clara and the Nutcracker prince's voyage to the Land of Sweets. Information: (502) 583-4555; www.louisvillepalace.com, www.nutcrackerinanutshell.com.

"The Nutcracker" from Bolshoi Ballet

Dec. 21, 12:55 p.m.

The Bolshoi Ballet's "Nutcracker" choreographed by Alexander Gorsky based on the original by Marius Petipa. Screening locations: Cinemark Mall St. Matthews, 5000 Shelbyville Road, (502) 259-9649; Preston Crossings 16, 9700 Preston Crossing Blvd., (502) 961-9700. Information: www.fathomevents.com/event/the-royal-opera-house-ballet-series.

MUSIC

A Philharmonia Christmas

Louisville Philharmonia — The Musicians' Orchestra

Beargrass Christian Church, 4100 Shelbyville Road

Dec. 5, 7:30 p.m.; Dec. 6, 1:30 p.m.

The full orchestra of Louisville Philharmonia presents a free concert with musical holiday favorites, including "O Holy Night" and "Sleigh Ride." Information: (502) 438-8331; www.louisvillephilharmonia.org.

O Come, Emmanuel: An Advent Celebration

Southern Baptist Theological Seminary, Alumni Chapel, 2825 Lexington Road

Dec. 6, 7:30 p.m.

A gospel-centered Christmas worship gathering based on the themes of Advent with three local worship ministries: Sojourn Music, Sovereign Grace Music and Highview Baptist Worship Ministry. The evening also includes music by tenor Philip Webb. Information: (502) 897-4115, events.sbts.edu/christmasconcert.

Thoroughbred Chorus

Memorial Auditorium, 970 S. Fourth St.

Dec. 6, 1:30 and 7:30 p.m.

The Thoroughbred Chorus is still going strong, having performers who won the silver medal in this year's International Barbershop Harmony Society competition. Information: (502) 583-7469; visit www.thoroughbredchorus.com.

Christmas Wonderland: Family Holiday Memories

Louisville Chorus

St. Mary's Catholic Church, 415 E. Eighth St., New Albany, Ind.

Dec. 6, 6 p.m.

For the 17th year, the chorus performs at St. Mary's in a concert featuring Holiday Family Children's Choir under director Paul Stiller and St. Mark's UCC Cherub and Youth Choirs under director Sandy Carter. For information, call (502) 968-6300 or visit www.louisvillechorus.org.

Winter Concert: Holiday Magic

VOICES of Kentuckiana

Eifler Theatre, The Clifton Center, 2117 Payne St.

Dec. 6, 7 p.m., and Dec. 7, 4 p.m.

The first holiday concert under its new artistic director, Jeff Buhrman, the chorus presents an eclectic mix of music that even includes a Bollywood number. Information: (502) 583-1013; visit voicesky.org.

Holiday Pops Spectacular

Indiana University Southeast Ogle Center, 4201 Grant Line Road

Dec. 6, 7:30 p.m.; Dec. 7, 3 p.m.

A concert featuring a range of popular music with IU Southeast's band, orchestra and choirs with special guests vocalist Tim King and Derby Dinner Playhouse actor J.R. Stuart. For information: (812) 941-2525; www.oglecenter.ius.edu.

Christmas at Immaculate Conception, Carols of the Nativity

Louisville Chorus

Immaculate Conception, 502 N. Fifth St., La Grange

Dec. 7, 4 p.m.

The chorus will sing with Julianna Horton at the organ. For information, call (502) 968-6300 or visit www.louisvillechorus.org.

Sweet Was the Song the Virgin Sang

Emilie Strong Smith Chamber Music Series

Locust Grove, 561 Blankenbaker Lane

Dec. 7, 5:30 and 7 p.m.

The Locust Grove Chamber Musicians present English, Scottish and Early American Yuletide music, which the Clark and Croghan families would have heard in the late 1700s and early 1800s when they lived at Locust Grove. For more information, call (502) 897-9845 or visit www.locustgrove.org.

Holiday Choral Festival Presented by Classical 90.5, WUOL

St. Martin of Tours Catholic Church, 730 E. Gray St.

Dec. 7, 7 p.m.

Several choirs perform, including the Louisville Chamber Choir, Voces Novae, Protus and Youth Performing Arts School Women's Choir. Information: www.wuol.org. Tickets: (877) 435-9849; ticketfly.com.

Christmas at St. Brigid: Carols of the Nativity

Louisville Chorus

St. Brigid Catholic Church, 1520 Hepburn Ave.

Dec. 14, 4 p.m.

The chorus will sing, with Julianna Horton at the organ. Information: (502) 968-6300; www.louisvillechorus.org.

Ring-a-ling, Jing-a-ling

Louisville Youth Orchestra's Holiday Concert

Youth Performing Arts School, 1517 S. Second St.

Dec. 14, 4 p.m.

Holiday classics and twists on seasonal favorites make up this concert. Information: (502) 896-1851; www.lyo.org.

Jim Brickman: On A Winter's Night

Brown Theatre, 315 W. Broadway

Dec. 18, 7:30 p.m.

The best-selling solo pianist Jim Brickman celebrates the season. Information: (502) 775-7777, http://www.kentuckycenter.org.

Gloria and Messiah

Louisville Master Chorale

Cathedral of the Assumption, 433 S. Fifth St.

Dec. 21, 2:30 p.m.

The concert includes Vivaldi's "Gloria" and Handel's "Messiah." Also on the program are two carol fantasies by Mack Wilberg, the familiar "The First Noel" and "Joy to the World." The concert includes soprano Selena Walker, mezzo-soprano Maggie Schwenker, tenor Tim King and baritone John Whittlesey. A pre-concert talk with University of Louisville professor John Hale starts at 1:45 p.m. Information: (502) 657-5248; www.louisvillemasterchorale.org.

A Festival of Nine Lessons and Carols

St. Francis in the Fields Episcopal Church, 6710 Wolf Pen Branch Road, Harrods Creek

Dec. 21, 5 p.m.

The music is a gem of the Anglican tradition and pairs readings about the birth of Christ with one or more carols of the season. This free concert is performed by the choirs of St. Francis in the Fields and a full orchestra. Information: (502) 228-1176; www.stfrancisinthefields.org.

THEATER

"Rudolf the Red-Nosed Reindeer: The Musical"

Brown Theatre, 315 W. Broadway

Dec. 6, 2 p.m. and 7 p.m.

The musical of the beloved reindeer that is faithful to the animated television special that debuted in 1964 with new characters for the story, such as Hermey the Elf and Yukon Cornelius, and a bevy of clever tunes. Information: (502) 584-7777; www.kentuckycenter.com.

"A Christmas Carol"

Actors Theatre of Louisville

316 W. Main St.

Through Dec. 23

This year brings a completely redesigned production with new sets, props and costumes, along with the story that still has the ghosts, Tiny Tim and Scrooge, who goes from arrogant to grateful in the course of a night. Information: (502) 584-1205 or (800) 428-5849; www.actorstheatre.org.

"A Wonderful Life"

Derby Dinner Playhouse

525 Marriott Drive, Clarksville, Ind.

Through Dec. 31

Based on Frank Capra's classic film, the play tells the story of George Bailey, who puts delays his own dreams to help others and finds himself unhappy and questioning his own life. That is, until he is visited by an angel on Christmas Eve. Information: (812) 288-8281; www.derbydinner.com.

"The Most Famous Reindeer of All"

Derby Dinner Playhouse

525 Marriott Drive, Clarksville, Ind.

Through Dec. 22

The story of Rudolph, the reindeer and unlikely hero who helped Santa fulfill important holiday duties. Santa will be at every performance. Information: (812) 288-8281; www.derbydinner.com.

"A World War II Radio Christmas"

Hayswood Theatre

115 S. Capitol Ave., Corydon, Ind.

Through Dec. 14

A re-creation of a 1940s radio show broadcasting on Christmas Eve and honoring the troops during WWII. Features music of the era. Information: (812) 738-2138; www.hayswoodtheatre.com.

"A Homeless Holiday"

Bunbury Theatre

The Henry Clay, 604 S. Third St.

Dec. 5-21

Written by Bunbury Theatre's producing artistic director Juergen K. Tossmann, the play tells the story of Meryl, who gives his tux to a Jehovah's Witness before he is to attend a ceremony to receive a prestigious horseman's award. His family is not too happy and fret when they learn that Meryl could inherit the family fortune. Information: (502) 585-5306; www.bunburytheatre.org.

"A Christmas Story"

Shelby County Community Theatre

801 Main St., Shelbyville

Dec. 6-14

The story of the boy who just wanted a BB gun, first written by Jean Shepherd before becoming a favorite film and then a play. Information: (502) 633-0242, www.shelbytheatre.org.

"The Best Christmas Pageant Ever"

Stage One

Kentucky Center, Bomhard Theater, 501 W. Main St.

Dec. 6-20

While some holiday plays have Elvis impersonators, "The Best Christmas Pageant Ever" does not. Instead, it has the Herdmans who lie, cheat, smoke, steal and look to topple the church pageant. But they don't, much to everyone's surprise. Information: (502) 584-7777, (800) 775-7777; www.kentuckycenter.org, www.stageone.org.

"Haul Out the Holly"

Vault1031

1031 S. Sixth St.

Dec, 12, 13, 19 and 20, 7:30 p.m.

A holiday revue with a special appearance by Vault1031 co-artistic director Barb Cullen singing her original song "Comin' Home." Information: (502) 895-8165; www.vault1031.com.

"The Kings of Christmas"

The Bard's Town Theatre

1801 Bardstown Road

Dec. 12-22

This play by Bard's Town's co-owner Doug Schutte about the unconventional King family, is out for its third holiday season. Among the family's characters is the long-lost patriarch who was an Elvis-impersonating magician. The family tries to balance celebrating the holiday with commemorating their loss. (It happened during a nationally televised magic show.) But this year is a bit different, in part due to a homecoming by the family's black sheep. Information: (502) 749-5275; www.thebardstowntheatre.org.

Reporter Elizabeth Kramer can be reached at (502) 582-4682. Follow her on Twitter at @arts_bureau.
